title: Testing the role of mediterranean thermohaline circulation as a sensor of transient climate events and shaker of north atlantic circulation
abstract: The Mediterranean Sea is an excellent sensor of transient climate conditions at different time scales. Changes in Mediterranean water properties result from complex interactions between the Atlantic inflow, local climate and north and south atmospheric teleconnections. In turn, Mediterranean outflow waters spill into the Atlantic Ocean, thus acting as a net salt and heat source for the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC). Climate models anticipate changes in these circulation systems within decades; thus it becomes critical to understand the natural range of variations in the Mediterranean Thermohaline Circulation (MedTHC) and whether these can alter the AMOC. An innovative approach, based on both well-established and newly-developed analytical methods will be applied to characterize, qualitatively and quantitatively, past changes in the MedTHC dynamics. Specific time windows representing very different transient periods (18-14 ka BP; 9.5-6.5 ka BP and the last 2 kyr) will be targeted in order to understand the distinctive role that individual forcing mechanisms exerted in controlling MedTHC changes. Particular emphasis will be placed on building robust regional chronologies and proxy records with unprecedented high-resolution. This approach will combine proxy data from sediment cores and deep-sea corals along the main paths of water masses as they cross the Mediterranean basins and exit into the North Atlantic. This paleo-data analysis will be complemented with novel climate model paleo-simulations to test the sensitivity of the AMOC to changes in Mediterranean outflow under varying AMOC conditions. The main goals are to identify: (1) The natural range of MedTHC variability; (2) The forcings and inter-regional teleconnections driving MedTHC changes; (3) The associated impact onto the AMOC. The assessment of the forcings controlling MedTHC and the ensuing impact on the AMOC will allow us to gauge the consequences of future Mediterranean changes.

motivations: The Mediterranean Thermohaline Circulation (MedTHC) plays a crucial role in sensing transient climate events and influencing the North Atlantic circulation, but its natural variability and impact on the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) are not well understood.
Climate models predict changes in these circulation systems within decades, emphasizing the need to understand the MedTHC's dynamics and its potential to alter the AMOC.
objectives: Characterize past changes in the MedTHC dynamics during specific transient periods to understand the role of individual forcing mechanisms.
Build robust regional chronologies and proxy records with high-resolution to analyze MedTHC changes.
Test the sensitivity of the AMOC to changes in Mediterranean outflow under varying AMOC conditions using paleo-data analysis and climate model paleo-simulations.
methods: Apply innovative analytical methods to sediment cores and deep-sea corals to characterize past MedTHC dynamics.
Combine proxy data from various Mediterranean basins and the North Atlantic to analyze MedTHC changes.
Conduct novel climate model paleo-simulations to test the sensitivity of the AMOC to changes in Mediterranean outflow.
results: Identify the natural range of MedTHC variability and the forcings driving its changes.
Understand the impact of MedTHC changes on the AMOC.
Gauge the consequences of future Mediterranean changes on the AMOC and global climate.

Understanding the natural range of variations in the Mediterranean Thermohaline Circulation (MedTHC) and its potential to alter the AMOC is critical, especially in light of anticipated changes in these circulation systems due to climate change.
objectives: Characterize past changes in the MedTHC dynamics qualitatively and quantitively using an innovative approach.
Understand the distinctive role that individual forcing mechanisms exerted in controlling MedTHC changes during specific transient periods.
Identify the natural range of MedTHC variability, the forcings and inter-regional teleconnections driving MedTHC changes, and the associated impact onto the AMOC.
methods: Apply both well-established and newly-developed analytical methods to analyze proxy data from sediment cores and deep-sea corals along the main paths of water masses.
Target specific time windows representing different transient periods to understand the role of individual forcing mechanisms in controlling MedTHC changes.
Complement paleo-data analysis with novel climate model paleo-simulations to test the sensitivity of the AMOC to changes in Mediterranean outflow under varying AMOC conditions.
results: Provide a comprehensive understanding of the natural range of MedTHC variability and the factors driving its changes.
Assess the impact of MedTHC changes on the AMOC, providing insights into the potential consequences of future Mediterranean changes.

motivations: The Mediterranean Sea acts as a sensitive indicator of transient climate conditions and influences the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation through its outflow waters.
Climate models predict changes in Mediterranean and Atlantic circulation systems within decades, making it critical to understand the natural variability of Mediterranean Thermohaline Circulation.
Understanding past Mediterranean circulation changes is essential to assess the potential consequences of future climate-driven changes in the region.
objectives: Characterize past changes in Mediterranean Thermohaline Circulation dynamics during specific transient climate periods.
Identify the natural range of Mediterranean Thermohaline Circulation variability and the forcings driving these changes.
Determine the impact of Mediterranean outflow variations on the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation.
methods: Apply established and newly-developed analytical methods to proxy data from sediment cores and deep-sea corals along Mediterranean water mass pathways.
Build high-resolution regional chronologies and proxy records for specific time windows representing different transient periods.
Conduct novel climate model paleo-simulations to test the sensitivity of Atlantic circulation to changes in Mediterranean outflow.
results: Establish the natural range of Mediterranean Thermohaline Circulation variability and its driving mechanisms.
Reveal the teleconnections between Mediterranean circulation changes and broader climate systems.
Provide insights into how future Mediterranean changes may impact Atlantic Ocean circulation.
